title: Carmine Nigro
text:
Carmine Nigro ( ; January 2, 1910 – August 16, 2001) was former World Champion <a href="Bobby%20Fischer">Bobby Fischer</a>'s first <a href="chess">chess</a> <a href="teacher">teacher</a>, from 1951–1956.
Biography.
"Mr. Nigro was possibly not the best player in the world, but he was a very good teacher." – Bobby Fischer 
Nigro was an American <a href="chess%20expert">chess expert</a> of near <a href="chess%20master">master</a> strength and an instructor. Nigro was President of the <a href="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> <a href="Chess">Chess</a> Club. This is where he met <a href="Bobby%20Fischer">Bobby Fischer</a> and in 1951 became his first chess teacher. Nigro (<a href="Elo%20rating%20system">rated</a> 2028) hosted Fischer's first chess tournament at his home in 1952.
Nigro introduced Fischer to future grandmaster <a href="William%20Lombardy">William Lombardy</a>, and, starting in September 1954, Lombardy began coaching Fischer in private.
In 1956, Nigro moved to <a href="Florida">Florida</a> and became a professional <a href="golf">golf</a> instructor. He did not give up teaching chess, though, and in 1996 he taught chess at the Meyer Jewish Academy. In 1999, Nigro moved to <a href="Peachtree%20City%2C%20Georgia">Peachtree City, Georgia</a>, to be close to his son Bill Nigro. He died in 2001, at the age of 91.
In film.
In the 2014 American biographical film "<a href="Pawn%20Sacrifice">Pawn Sacrifice</a>", Carmine Nigro was played by <a href="Conrad%20Pla">Conrad Pla</a>.
